newsitem.title: USA: US mortgage-backeds slip after durables report.
newsitem.headline: US mortgage-backeds slip after durables report.

text.p: U.S. mortgage-backed securities narrowed to Treasuries on Friday, with Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac pass-throughs outperforming Ginnie Maes.

Prices fell after the morning report on durable goods orders, which showed an overall rise of 1.6 percent in July. Ginnie Mae 30-year pass-throughs traded off 4/32 to 20/32, while Fannie Maes and Freddie Macs were off 6/32 to 19/32.
Trading activity was generally light, traders said.
Treasuries slid farther, with the 30-year bond off more than a point and the 10-year note off about 25/32 late on Friday afternoon.
Late on Friday, GNMA 30-year 8.0 percent coupons were off 17/32 at 100-25/32, yielding 107 basis points over 10-year Treasuries.
Comparable FNMAs were off 16/32 at 100-21/32, and FHLMCs were off 24/32 at 100-24/32.

Economists said the durables rise signaled strong demand for big-ticket items. "Capital spending is rising and manufacturing is back in an uptrend," said Astrid Adolfson, senior economist at MCM MoneyWatch Inc.
Next week, the market will get a look at home sales data and revised second-quarter gross domestic product.

Wall Street economists in a Reuters survey forecast existing homes sales fell to a 4.1 million unit annual rate in July against 4.18 million in June. They projected new home sales fell from 734,000 annualized to 728,000.
The economists forecast revised GDP will be unchanged at 4.2 percent.
